channel.description: The latest health and science news. Updates on medicine, healthy living, nutrition, drugs, diet, and advances in science and technology. Subscribe to the Health & Science podcast.

item.title: Invisibilia: Should Wild Bears Be Feared Or Befriended?
item.description: June 8, 2017 - A photographer who walks deep into the woods in search of a wild bear wonders if his curiosity will overcome his fear. Can bears and humans co-exist?
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 8, 2017 - A photographer who walks deep into the woods in search of a wild bear wonders if his curiosity will overcome his fear. Can bears and humans co-exist? http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/06/08/531787586/invisibilia-should-wild-bears-be-feared-or-befriended

item.title: Learn To Sniff Like A Dog And Experience The World In A New Way
item.description: June 8, 2017 - We humans think we don't have a very good sense of smell. But psychologist Alexandra Horowitz says dogs can show us how to train our noses so they give us a window into a secret world.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 8, 2017 - We humans think we don't have a very good sense of smell. But psychologist Alexandra Horowitz says dogs can show us how to train our noses so they give us a window into a secret world. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/06/08/531744473/learn-to-sniff-like-a-dog-and-experience-the-world-in-a-new-way

item.title: U.S. Pays Farmers Billions To Save The Soil. But It's Blowing Away
item.description: June 7, 2017 - Right now, the government rents farmland to help protect soil and water. But once the land is farmed again, the benefits disappear. Environmentalists want to change that.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 7, 2017 - Right now, the government rents farmland to help protect soil and water. But once the land is farmed again, the benefits disappear. Environmentalists want to change that. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/06/07/531894461/u-s-pays-farmers-billions-to-save-the-soil-but-its-blowing-away

item.title: If You See Dirty Water, Don't Just Gripe. Talk To The Cloud!
item.description: June 7, 2017 - Scientists and activists in India are training citizens to collect information on water issues like contamination — and upload it so it can be used to push for change.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 7, 2017 - Scientists and activists in India are training citizens to collect information on water issues like contamination — and upload it so it can be used to push for change. http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/06/07/527898124/if-you-see-dirty-water-dont-just-gripe-talk-to-the-cloud

item.title: 315,000-Year-Old Fossils From Morocco Could Be Earliest Recorded Homo Sapiens
item.description: June 7, 2017 - Scientists who found the fossils believe they are the remains of five people and far older than all previous finds. But how do the remains really fit into the bushy family tree of modern humans?
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 7, 2017 - Scientists who found the fossils believe they are the remains of five people and far older than all previous finds. But how do the remains really fit into the bushy family tree of modern humans? http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/06/07/531804528/315-000-year-old-fossils-from-morocco-could-be-earliest-recorded-homo-sapiens

item.title: How Alan Alda Makes Science Understandable
item.description:
June 7, 2017 - How do you communicate complex ideas effectively? How do scientists and doctors get their findings across to a needing public?
- http://the1a.org/shows/2017-06-07/alan-alda-makes-science-understandable-with-improv
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)

item.title: Travel Through Time With A Whale Detective
item.description: June 7, 2017 - Join NPR's Madeline Sofia on a tour of the largest collection of whale bones in the world. Curator Nick Pyenson takes us backstage to see Smithsonian specimens that aren't on display in museums.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 7, 2017 - Join NPR's Madeline Sofia on a tour of the largest collection of whale bones in the world. Curator Nick Pyenson takes us backstage to see Smithsonian specimens that aren't on display in museums. http://www.npr.org/2017/06/07/531112519/travel-through-time-with-a-whale-detective

item.title: Total Failure: The Mountain That Got Away
item.description:
June 7, 2017 - In 2014, Emily Harrington set out to climb the tallest peak in Southeast Asia. She had to turn back with the summit in sight.
- http://www.npr.org/2017/06/07/531582988/total-failure-the-mountain-that-got-away
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 7, 2017 - In 2014, Emily Harrington set out to climb the tallest peak in Southeast Asia. She had to turn back with the summit in sight. http://www.npr.org/2017/06/07/531582988/total-failure-the-mountain-that-got-away

item.title: Polar Photographer Shares His View Of A Ferocious But Fragile Ecosystem
item.description: June 6, 2017 - Paul Nicklen has spent decades documenting the Arctic and the Antarctic. "I want people to realize that ice is like the soil in the garden," he says. "Without ice the polar regions cannot exist."
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 6, 2017 - Paul Nicklen has spent decades documenting the Arctic and the Antarctic. "I want people to realize that ice is like the soil in the garden," he says. "Without ice the polar regions cannot exist." http://www.npr.org/2017/06/06/531735345/polar-photographer-shares-his-view-of-a-ferocious-but-fragile-ecosystem

item.title: PHOTOS: Here's What Climate Change Looks Like To Uganda's Coffee Farmers
item.description: June 6, 2017 - Coffee is Uganda's most valuable industry, but climate change could cut production by half by 2050. Small farmers there are already feeling the effects, as they document in these photos.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 6, 2017 - Coffee is Uganda's most valuable industry, but climate change could cut production by half by 2050. Small farmers there are already feeling the effects, as they document in these photos. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/06/06/531580368/photos-here-s-what-climate-change-looks-like-to-uganda-s-coffee-farmers

item.title: VIDEO: Get To Know The Bloodthirsty (But Cuddly) Vampire Bat
item.description: June 6, 2017 - In Latin America, they drink the blood of big animals and can spread rabies. Livestock die. So do people. Ranchers want to wipe the bats out. Does anyone think that's a bad idea?
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 6, 2017 - In Latin America, they drink the blood of big animals and can spread rabies. Livestock die. So do people. Ranchers want to wipe the bats out. Does anyone think that's a bad idea? http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/06/06/529853739/video-get-to-know-the-bloodthirsty-but-cuddly-vampire-bat

item.title: Researchers Ferret Out Information From White House Visitor Logs
item.description: June 6, 2017 - President Trump has decided to change President Obama's policy of making the White House visitor log public. A new study explores what kind of information is contained in the White House visitor log.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 6, 2017 - President Trump has decided to change President Obama's policy of making the White House visitor log public. A new study explores what kind of information is contained in the White House visitor log. http://www.npr.org/2017/06/06/531701357/researchers-ferret-out-information-from-white-house-visitor-logs

item.title: Trump Administration Seeking Permits For Seismic Air Gun Surveys In Atlantic
item.description: June 5, 2017 - The proposal would allow five energy companies to incidentally harass ocean wildlife by using seismic air guns for oil and gas exploration, much to the chagrin of environmental groups.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 5, 2017 - The proposal would allow five energy companies to incidentally harass ocean wildlife by using seismic air guns for oil and gas exploration, much to the chagrin of environmental groups. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/06/05/531608746/trump-administration-seeking-permits-for-seismic-air-gun-surveys-in-atlantic

item.title: Scientists Discover A Scorched Planet With A Comet-Like Tail
item.description: June 5, 2017 - The planet called KELT-9b is around three times more massive than Jupiter. It orbits a blue star about 650 light-years away from Earth that's nearly twice as hot as our own sun.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 5, 2017 - The planet called KELT-9b is around three times more massive than Jupiter. It orbits a blue star about 650 light-years away from Earth that's nearly twice as hot as our own sun. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/06/05/531561840/scientists-discover-a-scorched-planet-with-a-comet-like-tail

item.title: CEO Of Electric Power Giant Criticizes Trump Decision To Withdraw From Paris Climate Agreement
item.description: June 4, 2017 - NPR's Lulu Garcia-Navarro talks with Nick Akins, head of American Electric Power, about his reaction to President Trump's decision to withdraw from the Paris climate agreement.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 4, 2017 - NPR's Lulu Garcia-Navarro talks with Nick Akins, head of American Electric Power, about his reaction to President Trump's decision to withdraw from the Paris climate agreement. http://www.npr.org/2017/06/04/531444376/ceo-of-electric-power-giant-criticizes-trump-decision-to-withdraw-from-paris-cli
